reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s framing of the “default” distribution over futures conditional on survival and absent serious de dicto optimization, arguing this abstraction treats society as a unitary agent and misses competitive/jurisdictional dynamics that dominate key domains (space, digital rights, resource grabs). That is moderately central because the essay explicitly conditions on a particular baseline process for “no serious coordinated efforts,” and its conclusions about how likely mostly-great futures are depend on that distribution; if the baseline were badly misspecified, some probability claims and intuitions about “accidental” near-eutopia could shift. However, the essay’s main thesis is largely about value fragility / moral fussiness (narrow target) across many moral views, which can remain true even under a more realist competitive baseline; indeed, competitive lock-in may even support “no easy eutopia” rather than undermine it. Strength is therefore limited: it doesn’t clearly refute the core conclusion, but it does raise a substantive modeling objection to how the question is posed and what the “default” entails. Correctness is fairly high: it’s plausible that governance is multi-agent, that partial coordination plus competition can cause lock-in and competitiveness selection, and that this affects distributions; but it overstates by implying the essay relies on a “global common-sense utopia baseline,” whereas the essay uses common-sense utopia mainly as an illustrative case and explicitly allows many failure modes, including lock-in and political defeat of minority moral views. Clarity is high and dead weight low; it stays focused on one issue (baseline political-economy/equilibrium assumptions). Overall impact is modest because the critique mostly suggests a different (arguably even more pessimistic) default rather than showing the essay’s argument is wrong.
title: Jurisdictional lock-in and bloc competition dominate over unified moral drift
